q: What are the signs of a dental abscess?
a: Signs of a dental abscess include intense toothache or pain in your gums, redness inside the mouth or outside the mouth on the face or jaw, sensitivity to hot or cold food and drink in the affected area, a bad taste in your mouth, difficulty opening your mouth and chewing food, and a swollen face or jaw.

q: What should I do if I think I have a dental abscess?
a: You should ask for an urgent dentist appointment or get help from NHS 111. Do not go to a GP surgery as they will not be able to give you dental treatment.

q: How can I ease the pain caused by a dental abscess?
a: You can take painkillers such as ibuprofen or paracetamol (children under 16 should not take aspirin), eat soft foods, use a soft toothbrush to clean your teeth, and avoid having sugary, hot, or cold foods and drinks.

q: How is a dental abscess treated?
a: Dental abscesses are usually treated by a dentist who will drain away the pus. If a problem with your tooth has caused the abscess, you may need root canal treatment or the tooth may be removed. Painkillers and antibiotics may also be prescribed.

q: What are the causes of a dental abscess?
a: Dental abscesses usually occur when pus builds up beneath your teeth or gums due to an infection in your mouth. It can be caused by an impacted tooth, tooth decay, gum disease, mouth injury, or undergoing radiotherapy or chemotherapy.

q: How can dental abscesses be prevented?
a: To prevent dental abscesses, it is recommended to brush your teeth with fluoride toothpaste at least twice a day, clean between your teeth using floss or interdental brushes, replace your toothbrush regularly, and have regular dental check-ups. Avoid using mouthwash immediately after brushing and do not smoke.

q: What should I do if I need to see a dentist in an emergency or out of hours?
i: If you do not have a dentist or cannot get to an emergency appointment
a: You can call 111 or get help from 111 online. They can provide information on where you can get help for your symptoms or find a dentist near you. Please note that there may be a fee for emergency appointments.

q: When should I call 999 or go to A&E for a dental abscess?
a: You should call 999 or go to A&E if you are finding it hard to breathe, have a swollen or painful eye, sudden problems with your eyesight, or a lot of swelling in your mouth.

q: What should I do if my dentist is closed and I have a dental abscess?
a: You can call your dentist's answerphone, which may provide instructions. If you cannot reach your dentist or do not have one, you can call 111 or get help from 111 online for guidance on where to get help for your symptoms.

q: When should I avoid using mouthwash?
a: It is recommended not to use mouthwash immediately after brushing your teeth.

q: What are the signs of a dental abscess?
a: Signs of a dental abscess include: intense toothache or pain in your gums, redness inside the mouth or outside the mouth on the face or jaw, sensitivity to hot or cold food and drink in the affected area, a bad taste in your mouth, difficulty opening your mouth and chewing food, and a swollen face or jaw.

q: How can I ease the pain caused by a dental abscess?
a: There are some things you can do to help ease the pain, such as taking painkillers like ibuprofen or paracetamol (children under 16 should not take aspirin), eating soft foods, using a soft toothbrush to clean your teeth, and avoiding sugary or very hot/cold foods and drinks.

q: What is the treatment for a dental abscess?
a: Dental abscesses are usually treated by a dentist. The dentist will drain away the pus and may perform a root canal treatment or remove the tooth if necessary. Local anesthesia is used to ensure you don't feel any pain. Painkillers and antibiotics may also be prescribed.

q: What are the causes of a dental abscess?
a: Dental abscesses usually occur when pus builds up beneath the teeth or gums due to an infection in the mouth. Causes can include impacted teeth, tooth decay, gum disease, injuries to the teeth, gums or mouth, and undergoing radiotherapy or chemotherapy.

q: How can I prevent dental abscesses?
a: To prevent dental abscesses, you should brush your teeth with fluoride toothpaste at least twice a day, clean in between your teeth daily using floss or interdental brushes, replace your toothbrush every 1 to 3 months, and have regular dental check-ups. a: If you do not have a dentist or cannot get to an emergency appointment, you can call 111 or get help from 111 online. They can tell you where you can get help for your symptoms. You may have to pay for your appointment.
